title: Proverbs Chapter 30 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Proverbs chapter 30 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Proverbs Chapter 30 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Proverbs Chapter 30.

questions.question: Who is the author of the words in Proverbs Chapter 30?
questions.correctAnswer: Agur the son of Jakeh
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:1 states that these are the words of Agur the son of Jakeh.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:2, how does Agur describe himself?
questions.correctAnswer: More brutish than any man
questions.explanation: Verse 2 shows Agur saying he is more brutish than any man and lacks understanding.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Proverbs 30:5 says, 'Every word of God is ______: he is a shield unto them that put their trust in him.'
questions.correctAnswer: pure
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:5 clearly states that every word of God is pure.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 30:6 warn against doing?
questions.correctAnswer: Adding to God's words
questions.explanation: Verse 6 warns not to add to God's words lest He reprove and the person be found a liar.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:8, what two things does Agur ask to be removed far from him?
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity and lies
questions.explanation: Verse 8 requests removal of vanity and lies from Agur's life.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 30:10 advises accusing a servant to his master.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 10 tells not to accuse a servant to his master, lest the accuser be found guilty.

questions.question: Which generation is described in Proverbs 30:11?
options: Those who curse their father and do not bless their mother
questions.correctAnswer: Those who curse their father and do not bless their mother
questions.explanation: Verse 11 describes a generation that curseth their father and doth not bless their mother.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:15, how many daughters does the horseleach have?
questions.correctAnswer: Two
questions.explanation: Verse 15 says the horseleach has two daughters crying, 'Give, give.'

questions.question: What are the four things that are never satisfied as listed in Proverbs 30:16?
options: The grave, the barren womb, the earth not filled with water, and the fire
The sea, the sky, the earth, and the sun
The lion, the wolf, the bear, and the serpent
The wise, the foolish, the rich, and the poor
questions.correctAnswer: The grave, the barren womb, the earth not filled with water, and the fire
questions.explanation: Verse 16 lists these four as things that say not, 'It is enough.'

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 30:19 mentions the way of a lion in the air.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 19 mentions the way of an eagle in the air, not a lion.

questions.question: What is the behavior of the adulterous woman as described in Proverbs 30:20?
options: She eats, wipes her mouth, and claims innocence
questions.correctAnswer: She eats, wipes her mouth, and claims innocence
questions.explanation: Verse 20 describes her as eating, wiping her mouth, and saying she has done no wickedness.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four things the earth cannot bear listed in Proverbs 30:21-23?
options: A fool when he is filled with meat
An odious woman when she is married
questions.correctAnswer: A wise king ruling justly
questions.explanation: Verses 22-23 list the first three options, but a wise king is not included.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:25, what do ants do despite not being strong?
options: Prepare their meat in the summer
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare their meat in the summer
questions.explanation: Verse 25 describes ants as not strong, yet they prepare their meat in summer.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 30:28 tells us that the spider can be found in kings' palaces.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 28 states that the spider takes hold with her hands and is in kings' palaces.

questions.question: Which animal is described as strongest among beasts in Proverbs 30:30?
questions.correctAnswer: Lion
questions.explanation: Verse 30 describes the lion as strongest among beasts and not turning away for any.

medium.title: Proverbs Chapter 30 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Proverbs Chapter 30 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about God's power and wisdom. Based on Proverbs 30, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God alone has established all the ends of the earth and controls the wind and waters.
Human wisdom is greater than divine understanding.
Man can fully comprehend God's name and works.
The wind and waters are beyond God's control.
questions.correctAnswer: God alone has established all the ends of the earth and controls the wind and waters.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:4 teaches that God alone has ascended to heaven, gathered the wind, bound the waters, and established the earth's ends, showing His supreme power and wisdom. This is supported by verses 5 and 6 emphasizing God's trustworthy word.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 30 teach us about humility in our understanding?
options: The speaker admits he is more brutish and lacking understanding compared to others.
The speaker claims to have great wisdom and knowledge.
One should boast about their intelligence.
Humility is unnecessary if one is learned.
questions.correctAnswer: The speaker admits he is more brutish and lacking understanding compared to others.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:2-3 shows Agur's humility in declaring he is more brutish than any man and lacks wisdom and knowledge, teaching believers to recognize their limitations and rely on God's wisdom.

questions.question: A believer is tempted by both material wealth and poverty. According to Proverbs 30, what should they pray for?
options: Neither poverty nor riches, but food convenient for them.
Only great riches to be secure.
Abundance of riches and poverty alternately.
questions.correctAnswer: Neither poverty nor riches, but food convenient for them.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:8 teaches to pray for neither poverty nor riches but for sufficient provision to avoid denying God or falling into theft, promoting contentment and integrity (also see verses 7-9).

questions.question: What warning does Proverbs 30 give about adding to God's words?
options: Adding to God's words may lead to being reproved and found a liar.
It is good to add to God's words for clarity.
Adding to God's words is encouraged for better understanding.
One should ignore God's words and create their own.
questions.correctAnswer: Adding to God's words may lead to being reproved and found a liar.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:6 warns not to add to God's words to avoid His reproof and being found a liar, emphasizing obedience and reverence for Scripture (also see verses 5 and 7).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 30 advise us to treat servants and others under authority?
options: Do not accuse a servant to his master to avoid guilt.
Accuse servants freely to correct them.
Serve only those who serve you.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not accuse a servant to his master to avoid guilt.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:10 cautions against accusing a servant to his master, warning that it may bring curses upon the accuser and cause guilt, teaching kindness and discretion in relationships (see also verses 11-14 about generational behavior).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 30 say about contentment and avoiding denial of God?
options: If one is full, they may deny the Lord; if poor, they may steal and profane God's name.
Riches always lead to denying God.
questions.correctAnswer: If one is full, they may deny the Lord; if poor, they may steal and profane God's name.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:9 explains the danger of both abundance and want leading to denial or sin, urging believers to seek balanced provision and maintain integrity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 30, it is wise to flatter and bless parents regardless of their behavior.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:11 states there is a generation that curses their father and does not bless their mother, indicating that honoring parents is expected but not always practiced, highlighting the importance of obedience and respect in family life.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 30 teach about self-righteousness?
options: Some consider themselves pure but are not washed from filthiness.
Self-righteousness is praised as true holiness.
Everyone who claims purity is actually pure.
questions.correctAnswer: Some consider themselves pure but are not washed from filthiness.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:12 warns of a generation that is pure in their own eyes but unclean, teaching humility and self-examination in spiritual life.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30, what are examples of things that are never satisfied?
options: The grave, the barren womb, the earth not filled with water, and fire that says 'It is enough.'
Man's desire for knowledge and power.
questions.correctAnswer: The grave, the barren womb, the earth not filled with water, and fire that says 'It is enough.'
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:15-16 describe these four things that never say 'It is enough,' illustrating insatiable needs or conditions, teaching contentment and awareness of life's limits.

questions.question: A believer faces strife due to anger. How does Proverbs 30 counsel about anger and conflict?
options: Forcing wrath brings forth strife, so controlling anger is wise.
Anger should be expressed freely to resolve issues.
Strife is inevitable and should not be resisted.
Anger is a sign of strength.
questions.correctAnswer: Forcing wrath brings forth strife, so controlling anger is wise.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:33 explains that just as churning milk produces butter and wringing the nose produces blood, forcing anger produces strife, encouraging self-control and peace.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 30 describe wise behavior in small creatures and what can we learn from it?
options: Ants prepare food in summer; conies build in rocks; locusts move by bands; spiders dwell in kings' palaces.
Small creatures are weak and unwise.
Wisdom is irrelevant to daily survival.
questions.correctAnswer: Ants prepare food in summer; conies build in rocks; locusts move by bands; spiders dwell in kings' palaces.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:24-28 highlights these small creatures' wise and diligent behavior, teaching believers practical lessons about preparation, security, teamwork, and resourcefulness.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 30 teaches that an adulterous woman openly admits her wickedness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:20 describes an adulterous woman as one who eats, wipes her mouth, and claims she has done no wickedness, illustrating deceit and denial in sin.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with pride after success. According to Proverbs 30, what is a wise response?
options: Lay your hand upon your mouth and be silent if you have done foolishly.
questions.correctAnswer: Lay your hand upon your mouth and be silent if you have done foolishly.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:32 advises self-restraint and silence when one has acted foolishly or thought evil, promoting humility and careful speech.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Proverbs 30 says, 'Surely the churning of milk bringeth forth _______, and the wringing of the nose bringeth forth _______.'
questions.correctAnswer: butter; blood
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:33 uses this metaphor to show that just as churning milk produces butter and wringing the nose produces blood, forcing anger produces strife, teaching the consequences of wrath.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 30 teach about trusting God's word?
options: Every word of God is pure and He is a shield to those who trust Him.
God's words are sometimes impure and unreliable.
Trust only in your own understanding.
God's word is conditional and changes often.
questions.correctAnswer: Every word of God is pure and He is a shield to those who trust Him.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:5 affirms the purity of God's word and His protection over those who place their trust in Him, encouraging faith and reliance on divine truth.

hard.title: Proverbs Chapter 30 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Proverbs Chapter 30.

questions.question: In Proverbs 30:4, who is described as having established all the ends of the earth?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:4 asks about one who has established all the ends of the earth, implying God's sovereign creation and control over all, reflecting divine omnipotence.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 30:5 say about every word of God?
options: Every word of God is pure
Every word of God is mysterious
Every word of God is hidden
Every word of God is harsh
questions.correctAnswer: Every word of God is pure
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:5 states that every word of God is pure and that God is a shield to those who trust Him, emphasizing the trustworthiness and holiness of God's word.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:6, what warning is given about adding to God's words?
options: You may be found a liar
questions.correctAnswer: You may be found a liar
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:6 warns not to add to God's words or He will reprove you and you will be exposed as a liar, emphasizing the seriousness of faithfully preserving Scripture.

questions.question: In Proverbs 30:8, what two things does Agur ask God to keep far from him?
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity and lies
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:8 records Agur's prayer asking God to remove vanity and lies, showing his desire for truth and integrity.

questions.question: What reason does Agur give in Proverbs 30:9 for asking neither poverty nor riches?
options: Lest he deny God or steal
questions.correctAnswer: Lest he deny God or steal
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:9 explains Agur's concern that too much wealth might lead him to deny the Lord, and too much poverty might cause him to steal and profane God's name.

questions.question: Which generation is described in Proverbs 30:11?
options: Those who curse their father and do not bless their mother
questions.correctAnswer: Those who curse their father and do not bless their mother
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:11 depicts a generation that curses their father and does not bless their mother, highlighting a theme of social and familial decay.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 30:15 metaphorically say about the horseleech's daughters?
options: They are never satisfied and keep crying 'Give, give'
They work hard to gather food
questions.correctAnswer: They are never satisfied and keep crying 'Give, give'
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:15 uses the imagery of the horseleech and its two daughters crying 'Give, give' to illustrate insatiable greed or desire.

questions.question: Which four things are said in Proverbs 30:16 to never be satisfied?
options: The grave, barren womb, earth not filled with water, fire
The sea, sky, mountains, and rivers
The lion, eagle, serpent, and man
The wise, fools, servants, and kings
questions.correctAnswer: The grave, barren womb, earth not filled with water, fire
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:16 lists these four things as never satisfied, symbolizing death, barrenness, thirst, and consuming fire respectively.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Proverbs 30:18-19 lists four things too wonderful to understand. Which of the following is NOT one of them?
options: The way of an eagle in the air
The way of a serpent upon a rock
The way of a ship in the midst of the sea
The way of a lion in the forest
questions.correctAnswer: The way of a lion in the forest
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:18-19 mentions the way of an eagle, serpent, ship, and man with a maid as too wonderful to understand; the lion in the forest is not listed here.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:20, how does the adulterous woman behave after her act?
options: She eats, wipes her mouth, and claims innocence
She seeks forgiveness from her husband
questions.correctAnswer: She eats, wipes her mouth, and claims innocence
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:20 describes the adulterous woman as eating, wiping her mouth, and saying she has done no wickedness, illustrating shameless denial.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four things the earth is disquieted by in Proverbs 30:21-23?
options: A fool when he is filled with meat
An odious woman when she is married
questions.correctAnswer: A king who is humble
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:21-23 lists disquieting things including a servant reigning, a fool fed, an odious married woman, and an heiress handmaid; a humble king is not mentioned.

questions.question: What characteristic is attributed to ants in Proverbs 30:25?
options: They prepare their food in summer despite their weakness
questions.correctAnswer: They prepare their food in summer despite their weakness
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:25 describes ants as weak but wise for storing food in summer, showing industriousness and foresight.

questions.question: Proverbs 30:28 mentions a spider in an unusual place. Where is it found?
questions.correctAnswer: In kings' palaces
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:28 notes the spider takes hold with her hands and is found even in royal palaces, symbolizing subtlety and presence in unexpected places.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 30:32 advises that if you have done foolishly or thought evil, you should keep silent by laying your hand on your mouth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:32 instructs that upon foolish or evil thoughts or actions, one should restrain oneself by being silent, symbolized by laying a hand on the mouth.

questions.question: What is the literary device used in Proverbs 30:33 comparing the churning of milk to the wringing of the nose?
questions.correctAnswer: Analogy
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:33 uses analogy to compare churning milk producing butter and wringing the nose producing blood, illustrating that forcing wrath produces strife.

theological.title: Proverbs Chapter 30 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Proverbs Chapter 30 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:4, which attribute of God is emphasized through rhetorical questions about His control over creation?
options: His omnipotence and sovereignty over all creation
His mercy and forgiveness toward sinners
questions.correctAnswer: His omnipotence and sovereignty over all creation
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:4 emphasizes God's omnipotence by asking who has ascended to heaven, gathered the wind, bound the waters, or established the earth's ends, highlighting His sovereign control. This theme aligns with Psalms 115:3 (God's sovereignty), Isaiah 40:12-14 (God's control over creation), Colossians 1:16-17 (Christ sustaining all things), and Revelation 4:11 (God as Creator).

questions.question: What warning does Proverbs 30:6 give regarding the words of God?
options: Do not add to His words to avoid being reproved
Always interpret His words with flexibility
Add explanations to make His words understandable
Ignore His words if they seem difficult
questions.correctAnswer: Do not add to His words to avoid being reproved
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:6 warns against adding to God's words, lest one be reproved and found a liar. This aligns with Deuteronomy 4:2 and Revelation 22:18-19, which prohibit altering God's revelation, affirming the doctrine of the sufficiency and purity of Scripture.

questions.question: What does Agur request from God in Proverbs 30:8 regarding his daily provision?
options: Neither poverty nor riches, but food convenient for him
To be free from all trials
questions.correctAnswer: Neither poverty nor riches, but food convenient for him
questions.explanation: Agur asks in Proverbs 30:8 for neither poverty nor riches but just enough food, expressing a desire for contentment and dependence on God. This echoes 1 Timothy 6:6-10 (godliness with contentment), Philippians 4:11-13 (learning contentment), and Matthew 6:31-33 (trusting God for provision).

questions.question: Which human attitude is condemned in Proverbs 30:12?
options: Being pure in one's own eyes but unclean
questions.correctAnswer: Being pure in one's own eyes but unclean
questions.explanation: Proverbs 30:12 condemns self-righteousness where a generation considers itself pure yet is unwashed from filthiness. This is consistent with Isaiah 64:6 (all are unclean), Romans 3:10-12 (none righteous), and Luke 18:9-14 (parable condemning self-righteousness).

questions.question: What consequence is described in Proverbs 30:17 for those who mock and despise their parents?
options: The ravens and young eagles will pick out their eyes
They will be blessed with wisdom
They will be exalted among men
questions.correctAnswer: The ravens and young eagles will pick out their eyes
questions.explanation: Verse 17 describes a vivid judgment upon those who mock their father and despise their mother, symbolized by ravens and eagles picking out their eyes. This reflects the biblical emphasis on honoring parents (Exodus 20:12; Ephesians 6:1-3) and the consequences of defiance (Proverbs 20:20).

questions.question: In Proverbs 30:15-16, which four insatiable things are identified?
options: The grave, the barren womb, the earth not filled with water, and fire
The sea, the wind, the sun, and the moon
Man's heart, the devil, sin, and death
questions.correctAnswer: The grave, the barren womb, the earth not filled with water, and fire
questions.explanation: These four things symbolize insatiable forces that never say 'It is enough,' illustrating natural and existential realities beyond human control (Proverbs 30:15-16). This motif aligns with Ecclesiastes 1:8 (never satisfied), Job 20:11 (insatiable appetite of the wicked), and Psalm 49:10 (death's inevitability).

questions.question: Which four creatures are described as 'little upon the earth but exceeding wise' in Proverbs 30:24-28?
questions.correctAnswer: Ants, conies, locusts, and spiders
questions.explanation: The passage extols the wisdom of these small creatures in their survival and behavior, illustrating God's providence and design (Proverbs 30:24-28). This wisdom parallels Job 12:7-10 (learning from creation), Matthew 10:29-31 (God’s care for creatures), and Romans 1:20 (God’s attributes shown in nature).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'four things too wonderful' in Proverbs 30:18-19?
options: They reveal mysteries of God's providence and human relationships
They are signs of the coming Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: They reveal mysteries of God's providence and human relationships
questions.explanation: The four mysterious ways—an eagle in the air, a serpent on a rock, a ship in the sea, and a man with a maid—highlight the inscrutable nature of God's providence and the complexity of human relations (Proverbs 30:18-19). This relates to Job 28:20-27 (God’s wisdom hidden), Ecclesiastes 3:11 (God’s timing), and Psalm 139:6 (God’s wondrous knowledge).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 30:5 describe the nature of every word of God?
options: Pure and a shield to those who trust Him
Subject to human error and interpretation
A mystery only for the wise
questions.correctAnswer: Pure and a shield to those who trust Him
questions.explanation: Verse 5 affirms the purity and protective nature of God's words toward believers, supporting doctrines of biblical inerrancy and divine protection (Psalm 18:30; Psalm 91:4; John 17:17; Ephesians 6:16).

questions.question: What generational behavior is condemned in Proverbs 30:11?
options: Cursing their father and not blessing their mother
questions.correctAnswer: Cursing their father and not blessing their mother
questions.explanation: Verse 11 condemns a generation that dishonors their parents, contrary to the fifth commandment (Exodus 20:12) and New Testament teachings on family respect (Ephesians 6:1-3). This sin disrupts social and spiritual order.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the phrase 'the horseleach hath two daughters, crying, Give, give' in Proverbs 30:15?
options: It symbolizes insatiable greed and desire
It refers to literal daughters of a leech
It speaks of peace and contentment
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes insatiable greed and desire
questions.explanation: The horseleach with two daughters crying 'Give, give' personifies unending greed. This metaphor aligns with biblical warnings about covetousness (Ecclesiastes 5:10; Luke 12:15; 1 Timothy 6:9).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the attitude of the adulterous woman in Proverbs 30:20?
options: She acts with shameless denial of wrongdoing
She repents sincerely and seeks forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: She acts with shameless denial of wrongdoing
questions.explanation: Verse 20 portrays the adulterous woman as eating and wiping her mouth, claiming innocence despite guilt, reflecting hypocrisy and deceit. This connects with Proverbs 6:25-29 and Romans 1:29-32 about sinful denial.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 30:33 teach about the relationship between anger and conflict?
questions.correctAnswer: Forcing wrath inevitably produces strife
questions.explanation: This verse uses vivid imagery to show that stirring anger will cause conflict, teaching the biblical principle that uncontrolled wrath leads to division, consistent with James 1:19-20 and Ephesians 4:26-27.

questions.question: Which generation characteristic is described by 'their teeth are as swords, and their jaw teeth as knives' in Proverbs 30:14?
options: A generation that devours the poor and needy
A generation that shows kindness and mercy
A generation that worships God sincerely
A generation that is humble and contrite
questions.correctAnswer: A generation that devours the poor and needy
questions.explanation: Verse 14 describes ruthless oppression of vulnerable people, illustrating social injustice condemned by Scripture (Psalm 10:18; Isaiah 10:1-2; James 5:1-6).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 30:21-23, what social situations cause the earth to be disquieted and unbearable?
options: A servant reigning, a fool filled with meat, an odious married woman, and a handmaid heir to her mistress
A just king ruling, a wise servant serving, a faithful wife loving, and a humble handmaid obeying
A prophet speaking falsely, a priest sinning, a judge bribed, and a soldier disobedient
questions.correctAnswer: A servant reigning, a fool filled with meat, an odious married woman, and a handmaid heir to her mistress
questions.explanation: These four social inversions disrupt order and cause unrest, highlighting biblical principles about authority, wisdom, and propriety (Romans 13:1-7; 1 Corinthians 11:3; Titus 2:3-5).
